text:
ANITA: I would
like to welcome you to this webinar on the seven
myths of venture capital-- tips for new and
aspiring entrepreneurs,

with Mike Lepech
and Ashmeet Sidana. Mike is an associate professor
of civil and environmental

engineering and a senior
fellow at the Woods Institute for the Environment
at Stanford University.

He's also the academic director
of the Stanford I2M program.

Ashmeet is a long-time
venture capitalist and is the founder
and chief engineer

of Engineering Capital. His experience includes managing
venture capital funds, CEO.

He serves on multiple boards and
is an experienced entrepreneur. Ashmeet received his MBA from
the Wharton School of Business.

He has a MS Computer Science
from Stanford University and a BS in Computer
Science from USC.

Ashmeet is an action
traveler and has summitted Mount Everest. For more information about
Mike and Ashmeet's experience,

please check out Stanford
online web pages. With that, I'm going to
hand the webinar over
to Mike and Ashmeet. Mike? MICHAEL LEPECH: Thanks, Anita.

Ashmeet, it's wonderful
to join you here today. I know that today, we truly have
a global webinar in that you're

grinning from your home
in beautiful Palo Alto, and I'm joining from
Seoul right now--

traveled here yesterday to work
at our research center, focused

on smart cities. And so, we truly have a global
presence for this webinar.

So one of the things that I
wanted to talk to you today were some of these myths
about venture capital.

And I think that
venture capital is one of those very
mythologic jobs,

such that people don't
know exactly what it is, but it sounds very
cool and almost has

a romantic view to it, in
that, oh, my gosh, you're picking these companies,
you're taking up through,

there's billionaires
and private jets, and all these other things. And what we want
to try to do here

is number one, talk to an
actual venture capitalist and work a bit
more about, maybe,

walking back some of those myths
about what venture capital is

and what venture capital,
more importantly, is not. And so, we'll do this
David Letterman style--

for those that remember
"David Letterman Late Night," except he needed
top 10 reason to get

through any specific topic. Here, we think we
can do it in seven,

and so we'll try to get there.  So first of all, welcome,
Ashmeet, and it's

really a joy to
be here with you. ASHMEET SIDANA: Thank you, Mike. It's a pleasure to be here.

MICHAEL LEPECH: So let's start
with number seven, right? A VC's job is to help you.

Isn't it the job of
the VC to help you? ASHMEET SIDANA:
That's a great place to start because that's a
pervasive myth that we VCs like

to promote. VCs like to project that
they are there to help you.

That's their job. That's the marketing
and the advertising that many venture firms do.

Unfortunately, that is
not the job of a VC. People walk into venture firms,
and I've had entrepreneurs

directly tell me, well,
you're going to help me recruit employees, right? Or you're going to help
me get customers, right?

Or how many people are
you going to help me get a partnership going with? And those are fair questions.

And VCs will help in all of
those ways, in some ways, but that's not
the job of the VC.

A VC's job is an investor's job. It is to make money. In other words, to buy low
and sell high in a company

that an entrepreneur
is starting, and that is the primary
focus of the VC. And I think entrepreneurs
and VC's relationships

sometimes get waylaid. What entrepreneurs
don't understand that while VC may help you as
a part of making themselves

successful at making
themselves a great investor, their primary job
is not to help you.

MICHAEL LEPECH: Yeah. Well, and given the
structure of the cap table,

incentives are aligned. The VC only does
well if you do well.

But there is
absolutely a separation of duties and good
corporate governance,

in that the VC is very
much like a member or actually, officially
a member of the board

of directors at a company,
which it is not the member-- It's not the board of
directors and members

of the board to help
the CEO find employees for a large Fortune 500
company or any size of company.

There is that
separation of powers in good corporate
governance, and I think what you're saying
is you have to view

this in very much the same way. ASHMEET SIDANA: Absolutely. At the formal
level, you're right.

There's a separation of powers. There is a governance system
that is implicit over there.

But also in a more
subtle and nuanced way, you can see people
getting misaligned. And here are two great examples.

When Uber was on its
hyper growth trajectory, Benchmark, very high
quality early stage firm,

was an investor on the board. And eventually, Benchmark
sued the founder CEO Travis.

So, trying to file
a lawsuit, showed up in front of his hotel room at
8 o'clock at night in Chicago--

there's a lot of stories about
this, and they're all true. Or they're not true,
but as many of them are true about what happened.

And that's a case where you had
a board member actively working against a CEO.

And I think that starts
to tease apart where this relationship can end up. They won't all end up there.

Hopefully, you'll see a line. Hopefully, you will be large
and successful companies. But you do need to
start with this premise

that the VC has
a different role, and you have a different
role as an entrepreneur.

MICHAEL LEPECH: Absolutely. But you're exactly
right when you

say that there is this
myth that, oh, yeah, this is going to be somebody
who's going to work for me

in addition to
giving me some money and allowing me to
build my company. They're going to be just a
part of the working team--

not exactly. Not exactly. ASHMEET SIDANA: It does
happen in the ideal case, but not always.

MICHAEL LEPECH: For sure. For sure. And then, I guess that
ties in with recognizing

that different VCs are
talented in different ways and have different skill sets.

And so, I know we're going
to get a little bit later to some of the types of
advice that a VC can give you,

but they may not even be able
to offer you the kind of help that you may need or think
that you need at that time.

ASHMEET SIDANA: Exactly right. MICHAEL LEPECH: All
right, number six.

A VC will tell you why
they actually passed. They won't?

ASHMEET SIDANA: This
is another myth. People will say that XYZ told
me that this is why they passed.

Passing, of course,
refers to a VC declining to invest in your company. And entrepreneurs
will, sometimes,

to their credit, ask the
VC, why did you pass? Why are you not
investing in my company?

And there are rare occasions
when VCs will tell you the actual reason, and there
are even rarer occasions

where they will tell you
the complete reason on why they passed, but
that really is rare.

The VCs incentives,
unfortunately, are not aligned to
sharing that information.

At the simplest level,
venture is an investing job, there's an
information asymmetry,

and so you don't want that
information to go out there. A VC does not want to share
exactly what their thought

process is, what their
investment criteria is, how they evaluated someone.

A nicer and a benign
reason is that VC may just want to keep a
relationship with you.

They don't want to
hurt your feelings. They thought the
CEO wasn't good, and they don't want to
tell them to their face

that they didn't
think they were good. And so, it could be
something as simple as that.

But there are also
many more reasons which range a gamut of--

the partner has a
different agenda, the firm has a different agenda,
the strategy is changing.

There are venture firms
that in the business, we like to call the living dead. In other words, venture
firms that don't really

have more capital
to deploy, that are just taking meetings
to keep their reputation,

to keep their presence
in the market, in the hope that they will
raise a new fund in the future.

And there are pernicious
effects like that that do pervade the market.

And so, it's very hard to find
out the real and actual reason why someone passed. Now, obviously, if
you could find it out,

it's very useful information. So I always encourage my
entrepreneurs to go and ask.

You have nothing to lose. But whatever you hear, take
it with a pinch of salt

and try to collect
multiple data points. And then try to triangulate and
see what is the real reason.

Is there are some learning
in it that you can get. Because this is the reason why
the venture firm passed on you.

My rule of thumb is you need
10 no's to really figure out what's going on in the market.

And here's a piece of advice. If you already have an investor
who you can trust, who is a VC,

or who knows how the
venture community works, a great way to find out
why someone actually passed

is to ask them to
do a back channel. In effect, a reverse reference. And say, OK, hey, John,
you passed on my company.

Can you let me know why? And offer the VC on a
professional courtesy out of a relationship,
which, hopefully,

your existing investor
has built with the firm, will be able to glean some
more truths over there.

But again, that
is with the caveat that it should be taken
with a pinch of salt and is probably not the
complete truth on what

actually happened over there. MICHAEL LEPECH: I
think it's interesting that you're talking
about the living dead,

and we talk about zombie
companies very often. Those that are just
hanging on, but they

can't get that next
round, and nothing seems to be moving forward. And we don't think about the
flip side of it, in which there

are sort of the living dead or
zombie venture funds, which,

as you said, don't have
any more capital to deploy, but they're looking to
raise that next round. And because all of this is
so much about reputation

and about that ability to
bring in the next really great founder, they
need to keep that up. And so it can be somewhat
confusing to say,

gosh, I thought you
really liked my company. I thought things were
really going well, and yet, you couldn't
write a check

or you didn't write a check. But in honesty, you
couldn't write a check, and that's really interesting.

ASHMEET SIDANA:
That's exactly right. They couldn't write a check
even if they wanted to. And the problem of zombie
firms in venture capital

is particularly bad because
traditionally, venture firms are raised with a
10 year fund cycle.

And as long as you
are an active manager, you get paid fees for
those entire 10 years.

In other words, you're getting
an income from the fund. And so, it is your
interest as a VC to pretend that you are
active to keep drawing

on those fees, which can
be substantial if there are substantial funds even
if you don't intend

to raise another fund or you
don't want to do it, not here. Of course, I'm clearly impugning
the objectives of someone

who behaves like that and
the motives of someone who is like that. But, look, we're all
human, VCs are human,

and we suffer from
these weaknesses. And I think it would
behoove an entrepreneur to recognize that that could
be going on in the market.

I should also add
that right now, we are in a very positive
market for venture capital.

We've had a great bull
run for the last 10 years, the market has been
up and to the right. It has accrued to the
benefit of venture capital.

COVID was obviously
an enormous tragedy in huge parts of the
world, but it actually

helped venture capital and
technology in some ways. And so if anything,
it has even further accelerated the flow
of capital towards VC.

And so I think the
problem of zombie firms is actually not
so bad right now.

But if and when the market
corrects-- and believe me, the market will correct-- we just don't know when.

I can guarantee it will correct,
the only question is when. At that point, I think
this will become,

once again, a very big problem. MICHAEL LEPECH: Yeah. No, with interest
rates being so low,

there is so much liquidity
looking for any kind of return, even though it might be
something very risky,

like investing in a
venture fund that-- you're right, it has
been that market,

and what it will correct. And we've seen it a few times
in sort of the Silicon Valley

space. It will be challenging. I think one of the other
things that you had said

was you always want
to be nice to people who are coming in
and picking to you because you never
know if they're going to be the person coming to
you with that next great idea.

And so you want to build
those relationships over time. A question came in
about specifically--

and since we're talking about
why you would pass or why you might not pass-- advice to female founders
of tech companies,

particularly coming
from Latin America, but more generally
to female founders. What are you looking for
in this type of profile?

ASHMEET SIDANA: So you
know, my perception is that it's unfortunate,
but female founders do have a higher bar or
higher burden just because

of the nature of
society, just because of the social norms
that we live in and the expectations
that have developed.

I think the good
news is that there are VCs who are working
actively to correct. There are people who are
very aware of this issue,

and so there are both
sides to this coin. But net net, I would
say today, there is a higher bar
and a higher burden

that they just need
to be aware of when they walk into the market. This is a marketplace for ideas.

It's a marketplace for money,
when you're talking to VCs. So you have to be aware of it.

You know, my mentor,
the person who I owe the most to being a VC
was actually a woman, Kathryn

Gould, who was one of the very
first GPs in Silicon Valley

and was the founder
of a great firm, helped me start Engineering
Capital eventually, and just a fabulous
venture capitalist

and a woman who started a
venture firm because she was unable to become a
partner in a great firm

and felt that that was the
only alternative left for her. And so she definitely had
a chip on her shoulder,

and she would often get
this question because just by virtue of being a woman VC,
a lot of women entrepreneurs

would walk in. And so you would meet a
lot of women entrepreneurs. And her advice, you
could simplify it

down to saying that the
best course of action is for female founders
to be relatively

oblivious to this
distinction that exists. Your job as an entrepreneur
is to do your best.

Making yourself more
aware of this issue is not going to
solve the problem. If your goal is to
solve the problem,

then there are better
ways to solve it. In other words, you could
become a politician, you could become a lawyer, you
could become a social activist,

you could become a journalist. There are many ways in which you
can address these issues that are more effective
and probably will

have a greater impact faster. By being an entrepreneur, you
are simply setting an example.

And your job as
an entrepreneur is to succeed in
building your company. That's job one,
that's job two, that

is the most important thing
you can do for yourself and the world is if you can
make that company successful

if you are an entrepreneur. And so once you
make that leap, then it just reduces to "what
does it take to make

your company successful?" What is the best
course of action that you need to take
to make your business

a non-traditional background, is
in a non-traditional location-- you mentioned Latin America,
obviously, which is obviously

a non-traditional
location for those of us who are sitting here
in Silicon Valley. But those are giant markets.

Those are emerging markets. Those are fast growing markets. And that's often where
there's more opportunity.

And so just have to play
by the rules of the game as they are placed in front of
you and do the best you can.

MICHAEL LEPECH:
Yeah, definitely. So a quick, funny question
that kind of came in.

It's a very
interesting question. You know, very often, I know
that there are investors that, kind of a few years
in, think of themselves,

oh man, I don't know if I
invested in this company correctly. I don't know if
this was a good-- I mean, we all have a little
bit of buyer's remorse from time

to time. And then one of
the questions that came in-- as a founder, is
it possible to lay off of VC if you don't want them anymore?

That gets a little harder
with the cap table. ASHMEET SIDANA: Yes. Very, very hard.

The way I say it is there is no
undo in the venture business. As an investor, once
you make an investment,

you are pretty much committed
and you're not going to get to back out of that.

Similarly, as an entrepreneur,
once you've selected a VC and you brought them on to your
cap table, there's no undo.

You cannot fire an investor. You can fire a CEO,
you can fire a VP,

you can redo the
entire management team, you can change your
product, you can put it into a different market, you
can do all kinds of things.

But those cap tables
are pretty rigid and can become boat
anchors in some cases.

And they are definitely
a source of stress, and that is why reputation
is so important. That is why diligence on
both sides is so important.

Just like we do diligence as VCs
before we make an investment, I always advise my CEOs, go
call some people off the list.

In other words,
not the reference list that the VC gave you. But go call some people that
that VC worked with in the past

and see what they say
behind the back of the VC. And you will learn a lot.

You will learn whether that
is the kind of person who you want to work with. That is the kind of
person who you will be

aligned with for the long haul. Firms have reputations
in addition to partners.

and there are firms who
are founder friendly and will accept, perhaps,
a less than optimal outcome

because that's the
best strategy for them. And you need to understand
that as an entrepreneur before you accept that money,
because once you take it,

you're pretty much
in it for life. MICHAEL LEPECH: Well,
and that also, I think, speaks to one of the other
questions that came in-- advice

for idea-stage founders. Be careful who you're working
with, even very early on,

and to say, hey, to your
cousin, to a friend, to somebody in the
family, hey, I'll give you

half of the company if
you do X, Y and Z for me because at that point,
they're an investor as well,

in many regards, because they
will be on that cap table. And they will be there forever
if it's structured that way.

And so you want
to be very careful very early on with making sure
you are thoughtful about who

you're going to bring in and
what you're going to offer. It's an incredibly
important point. ASHMEET SIDANA: Yes, Mike.

And the way I think an
entrepreneur can simplify this is that your job, obviously,
as an entrepreneur,

is to build a profit and
loss and a balance sheet. Everybody thinks of a business
in terms of consisting

of a P&L and a balance sheet. I'd say, well, you're really
managing three statements. You're managing your P&L, your
balance sheet, and your cap

table. And you have to be
thoughtful about how you are going to grow it. There's only 100% to go around.

That 100% can never change. And it really has to survive
the life of the company,

and so how are you going to
husband the growth of that cap table to eventual
success, whatever

your definition of success? An IPO, an M&A, there's only
100% to go around over there.

And it becomes a zero sum
game very, very quickly, and then you are at odds. You are sitting on the
opposite side of the table

from someone who was
your friend yesterday, and it's very uncomfortable. That leads to very, very
difficult conversations.

MICHAEL LEPECH: Indeed. Indeed. All right, let's get
back to the list. We're at number five.

A VC turning you down
means something's wrong with your business.

That's not true? ASHMEET SIDANA:
This is a huge myth, and one I wish every
entrepreneur would take to heart before they followed
my advice on the previous one,

which is go get feedback and
learn what the VC is saying. If you remember my answer
to the previous question,

you have to take what the VC
says with a huge grain of salt. And so that applies
to them saying

why they passed
implying something wrong with your company. In other words, don't over
rotate on the feedback

that you get from a VC. Sometimes, entrepreneurs
will say, oh, they told me my go-to-market is bad.

Well, that's the reason they
gave you why they passed. That doesn't necessarily
mean your go-to-market

is wrong or bad or is not
appropriate for the way you want to build your business
or for the product that you've

done. They may not have even
understood your product. They may not have even
understood your strategy. Or even if they
understood it, they

may not agree with
the risk-reward trade off of that strategy. Even if they agree with
the risk-reward trade

off with the strategy,
they may have chosen not to participate
in that because of other preferences
that they have

in their fund or other
companies that they have in their fund
completely unrelated to you. In other words, if I have just
taken-- if I'm a large fund

and I've just taken
10 consumer bets, I may not want to make
the 11th consumer bet. I may want an enterprise
bet for the 11th one.

It has nothing to
do with you having a wrong or a bad approach
to building your business.

And so it's important
for an entrepreneur to have the courage
of their convictions to be able to derive
from first principles

that they are building a good
business for the long term. VCs are famous for
being pattern matchers.

They are making quick decisions. They are trying to build
a portfolio on their side.

And that is not what you are
doing as an entrepreneur. As an entrepreneur,
you are building a business, ground up,
bottoms up, step by step,

for the long term. And following a non-traditional
or an unusual path is actually, many times,
the right thing to do.

It is the way in which you will
build a disruptive company. And so be very
cautious when a VC says

that you are doing something
wrong or interpreting that as necessarily wrong for you.

Simply take it as
one data point, out of many available to you,
to learn about your business,

to learn about the environment. Yes, that is their perception. Yes, that is how one
smart person, sitting

in one firm, who spent
an hour or two with you, thought you were doing. But you're doing that 24
hours a day, for years on end.

And there are lots of examples
of companies that were not understood by VCs early on.

You know, the entire
open source landscape is littered with VCs who
thought they would never build a big business.

Let's take the very first
successful company, Red Hat. Red Hat was recently acquired
by IBM for $30 billion,

the biggest acquisition
in IBM's history. I mean, $30 billion
is a massive outcome,

and here is a company-- obviously, in this
case, a public company and a very old company that have
been around for a long time--

but it started as an
open source company. All their products,
you could download from the internet for free.

And yet they built what was
eventually a $30 billion outcome over here.

So there are many ways
to build a company, there are many ways
to build a business, and you have to be creative.

MICHAEL LEPECH: Yeah. And one of the
words you had used, that is so important for people
to understand is "portfolio."

You know, much
like for all of us, we have a personal investing
portfolio where you're

going to invest in some
stocks and some other things, and you're trying to
create a mix of investments

for which you feel that
you're going to get a good risk-return ratio. And that doesn't mean
there aren't hundreds

of other great companies
out there, on the stock market, that you could buy. And in many regards, they
might be just as good.

However, if you've
already bought one of those other
competitors of theirs, you may not want to allocate
more of your capital

and sort of double
down on that one bet. The venture capitalist is very
much, as you've said before,

is an investor. And investors manage portfolios. And so you also
have to understand

that there may not be
something wrong with you, but rather you're
just duplicating a part of their portfolio
and they would choose

not to do this any longer. I guess maybe as a follow
up to that, when a venture

capitalist says,
you know, I really am going to have
to pass on this, but maybe you should go
talk to this other fund,

are they giving you an honest
recommendation that they think that other fund
might invest in you,

or are they just kind
of passing you off to kind of get you out of
the office and at least I sent them on their way with
some nice piece of information?

ASHMEET SIDANA: Like all
human communication, Mike, the answer depends.

There is no silver bullet
that anyone has developed. Otherwise, we wouldn't need
a justice system and courts

and journalists and
investigative reporters and all of this work to get to
the truth of the matter.

And I think,
ultimately, of course, this becomes a philosophical
question and, you know, what is the nature of truth?

But the answer depends. I have seen VCs who will go
out of their way to be helpful

and will genuinely
give you feedback, and then I've seen VCs who
can be quite cynical about it

and would want to take
advantage of the situation and perhaps abuse the trust
that you may be placing in them.

And so, like any human
population, it ranges-- there's an entire
range of people.

And you, as an
entrepreneur, have to make an evaluation,
a judgment of what it is that you are receiving,
with due caution, over there.

VCs do keep a lot of contacts. You know, that's
part of our job. And so we can give you
insight over there.

I will tell you, having
been a practicing VC now for over a decade, that our fear
on the other side of the table

is that many times,
entrepreneurs actually don't want to hear the truth. Many times, entrepreneurs
are not receptive to really

what they would be able to get. And so it is in our interest
to be demure, to just be quiet

and to avoid a confrontation. There's no reason to create
a confrontation there. And so VCs will sometimes take
the low road in that sense,

rather than taking
the high road-- or you could call it
the high road, I guess-- by just staying
quiet over there.

And so what I would
tell entrepreneurs is if you can somehow
communicate to the VC

that you are genuinely
looking for the best recommendation,
that best advice,

then you may get
a better answer. But at the end of
the day, you will have to evaluate how much weight
to put on that recommendation
and that answer. MICHAEL LEPECH: Yeah. No, it's a good--

you're right. It always depends on
what kind of relationship have you built through
those first few discussions

and whether or not they
think that you're somebody worth spending more time with,
and to give you that advice.

ASHMEET SIDANA: Yeah. MICHAEL LEPECH: All
right, number four. And this is one that
I think is, indeed,

a huge myth around
the world, certainly around Silicon Valley--
VCs are rich. VCs aren't rich. I mean, come on.

ASHMEET SIDANA: Well,
there are certainly some VCs who are rich. But there are also many
VCs who are not rich.

And I think it's
important to understand that for an entrepreneur
who's walking in, who is hoping to build a
relationship with a firm

and with a person. Let's first separate whether
an individual is rich

or whether a fund
has money, which is the money that they
are going to invest in you as an entrepreneur.

Those are not one
and the same thing. I fund is a distinct,
separate entity in which there are LPS, Limited
Partners, who hopefully,

presumably, are rich, who
have invested in that fund, whether through a
foundation or endowment,

whether it's a pension
fund, or perhaps even a high net worth individual
who has invested in that fund. That is the money that is
being invested in companies.

That is distinct and
separate from the individual who is doing the job of
a venture capitalist, who

is investing that money. Venture capital can be
a lucrative business in the long term, and
so if you're a good VC,

eventually, you should be rich. That's part of the
returns of that job.

But many VCs are
not rich, especially VCs who are junior, younger,
working at large firms

is where you see the maximum
disconnect that happens. And I have seen it lead to
some awkward situations.

You can be a Stanford MBA
who graduates and becomes a principal or an associate
at a very large venture firm.

And yes, you get a
nice salary, but you haven't become rich overnight. You just got a job at a large
venture firm, which is perhaps

managing billions of dollars. And I was personally
in a dinner once where

someone ordered a
$1,000 bottle of wine just as part of the dinner,
part of the conversation that

was going on. And I think it was
really uncomfortable for the other person because
it was inappropriate.

I don't think the entrepreneur
had recognized that. I mean, that's a
very large purchase

relative to a casual dinner
that someone will be doing. Now, there are lots of VCs
who wouldn't think twice

about spending $1,000
on a bottle of wine, but there are many VCs
who will remember that.

And I certainly noticed the look
of chagrin on people's faces

when that happened. And so you should
not presume that. I think that's incorrect. And just understand
that we are just

normal people who are doing
a job, in a different line of work, who are in
there who, depending

on the stage of career
they're on, maybe at different stages of wealth

MICHAEL LEPECH: Which is not

The traditional advice

The average venture
firm loses money. The average venture firm

So let that sink in. That's a really,
really poor investment,

if you are going to
invest in average. Venture capital tends
to follow the power law.

In other words, all the
returns are concentrated right at the top, and they are
disproportionately high.

In other words, if you can
be in a winning venture fund and a winning
venture firm, you

could make enormous returns. Much higher than you could make
in a traditional investment,

whether in the public markets
or even in the private markets. You can do extremely
well in those rare funds.

But the keyword there is
"rare" and the keywords there are "power law." And so you really
have to understand

what you're getting into. And so be very
cautious if you are investing in a venture fund.

While disproportionate
returns are possible, they are very risky, and even
the largest, most sophisticated

institutional investors
rarely invest more than 3, 4, or 5% of their entire
corpus in venture funds.

And so that should tell
you how risky it is. You can actually go
and see what numbers--

I don't know it off
the top of my head. You know what, the Stanford
endowment, the Yale endowment, except that these are very
sophisticated investors who

have an infinite time

sense of how risky it is.

So yes, it can be

happened in venture,

in terms of investing

MICHAEL LEPECH:

And here, you have someone

And it's very dangerous. You really, really

Usually, a managing director

Those titles are

in the minority cases. All the other
titles, they are not

equal to a general partner

So for example, almost all
